@stuartmorgan
Thank you for your comment and advice.

we should really have a design doc for the tooling plan before moving forward with a PR

I agree with you. Is it enough to add my idea to the description so that we can discuss? Or is there any other way?

Is linux still a build option (vs linux-x64 and linux-arm64 or similar)? If so, does it mean "same as host" or "x64"?

No, it isn't. I'm sorry for confusing you. I updated the description. Now, I want to run the Flutter SDK on an arm64 host.

How should the build output be structured for multi-arch output?

At the time of self-build, the build output will be output to build/linux/. It's the same as the current output directory structure. On the other hand, at the time of cross-build, it will be output to build/linux-cross/.
How about my idea?

For Linux, how is the sysroot handled?

I have considered that an user can specify a sysroot prepared by themselves in the build option. I think it would be better to have an option for them to freely specify sysroot. Because Flutter Engine has similar options.
$ flutter build linux --target-platform=linux-arm64 --target-sysroot=/target-sysroot-path

But If the Flutter SDK download the sysroot used to cross-build the Flutter Engine first, they don't need to prepare anything.

Is it enough to add my idea to the description so that we can discuss? Or is there any other way?

https://flutter.dev/docs/resources/design-docs


Is linux still a build option (vs linux-x64 and linux-arm64 or similar)? If so, does it mean "same as host" or "x64"?

No, it isn't. I'm sorry for confusing you. I updated the description. Now, I want to run the Flutter SDK on an arm64 host.

How should the build output be structured for multi-arch output?

At the time of self-build, the build output will be output to build/linux/. It's the same as the current output directory structure. On the other hand, at the time of cross-build, it will be output to build/linux-cross/.

Sorry, I wasn't clear. These weren't questions about how your patch works, these are questions that all stakeholders need to agree on what we want the solutions to be, not only for Linux, but for other platforms where we need this in the future such as Windows. (E.g., I'm not at all sold on having two different build directories whose contents depend on the host machine, vs., say, always doing linux/x64/... and linux/arm64/...)
And a design document is the best place to have a discussion like that.

I posted the design document. Please feel free to comment and review.
https://docs.google.com/document/d/19tzWySgtgtTA99XQsjx5Pg0SFJeZKXyUlYavR0EXv8c/edit?usp=sharing

The cause is that  dart-sdk-linux-arm64.zip does not contain the files under the dev_compiler directory. In addition, the dart-sdk for Linux arm64 in Dart SDK archive also does not contain these files. On the other hand, dart-sdk-linux-x64.zip contains these files.
It seems to be included only for x64 architectures and I think this is a dart-sdk issue. dart-lang/sdk#39312
For the moment, I copied the files contained in dart-sdk-linux-x64.zip to the local cache and I confirmed that a sample app works onRaspberry Pi4.

Thank you for your comments.

The cause is that dart-sdk-linux-arm64.zip does not contain the files under the dev_compiler directory. In addition, the dart-sdk for Linux arm64 in Dart SDK archive also does not contain these files. On the other hand, dart-sdk-linux-x64.zip contains these files.
It seems to be included only for x64 architectures and I think this is a dart-sdk issue. dart-lang/sdk#39312
For the moment, I copied the files contained in dart-sdk-linux-x64.zip to the local cache and I confirmed that a sample app works onRaspberry Pi4.

FWIW, just to provide some feedback on interest: I have been eagerly tracking this issue all week specifically because I want to be doing Flutter Web builds on ARM. I have been wanting to use cheaper ARM servers for deployment of my web sites and use cheaper ARM machines for my parallel CI on deployment and build, and even have a specific driving use case this week building a web interface on some ARM routers--on which I have been hoping to build the code in addition to just deploy it, as they have more than enough RAM, and I imagine a lot of my downstream users will find this to be the easiest way to prove the binary reproduction--and I couldn't honestly care less about native app stuff working on Linux ARM hosts as it isn't like I really ever see ARM machines locally / in real life that are running Linux (so discounting the Surface or an new Apple MacBook) except for the occasional Raspberry Pi attached to a monitor temporarily.
Regardless, I am definitely excited to see progress is at least being made on this front!

FYI. Here is the procedure for cross-build and running dart-sdk I tried. Basically cross-build procedure is as per the official wiki.

Build dart-sdk on Host PC (Ubuntu x64)

$ mkdir dart-sdk
$ cd dart-sdk
$ git clone https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/tools/depot_tools.git
$ export PATH="$PATH:$PWD/depot_tools"
$ fetch dart
$ cd dart
$ ./tools/build.py --no-goma -m release -a arm64
$ cd out/ReleaseXARM64/
$ tar zcf /tmp/dart-sdk.tar.gz dart-sdk


run Flutte SDK on Jetson Nano (Ubuntu arm64)

$ git clone https://github.com/flutter/flutter.git
$ export PATH=$PATH:./flutter/bin
$ tar xf dart-sdk.tar.gz

Replace dart-sdk after the error.
$ flutter doctor
  build error!!

$ rm -rf flutter/bin/cache/dart-sdk
$ cp -rf dart-sdk flutter/bin/cache

@HidenoriMatsubayashi is the work you're doing also able to be used for ARM (32bit)?

@flukejones
No, this PR doesn't support ARMv7 (32bit, armhf). This PR only focus ARMv8 (64bit, aarch64).

@HidenoriMatsubayashi would it be very hard at all for you to add the required parts to support ARMv7? I would be willing to share some of the burden but that means I'm switching to an unfamiliar domain.

In my opinion, I don't think it' hard. However, I have no authority to decide to do that (We can propose additional ARM 32bit support). In addition, I think currently most of the actual products that run Linux are ARM 64bit. Naturally, there are also ARM 32bit Linux systems.

I think it would be a good idea to include ARMv7 support at the same time. Currently the changes being introduced or merged so far break existing 32bit builds. I can test this as I am trying to get a flutter build layer running for yocto linux on an stm32mp1 dev board.

Building the artifacts for a new platform is a substantial effort. The cost for doing so should be discussed in a new issue and not done as a part of this PR.
What workflows do these changes break? We don't currently support 32bit arm as either a host or target platform on Linux, but if something was working by accident before that would be great to know.

@jonahwilliams I mention it here because these changes touch much of what is required for 32bit support and it would be good to have these changes allow for adding 32bit instead of assuming it will never be used. There are a number of issues that I've tracked down:

#74322
maintainer of meta-flutter for yocto, used with stm32mp1
flutter-rs engine builds needed to be disabled
article where ARM was used, no-longer working

I will create an issue to track this.

Using Termux or similar approach may be possible (as long as the app provides aarch64 userland and you have enough RAM - both will be impacted by how Android operates).
Android build tools aren't available for aarch64 afaik. Pretty much the mention of Android Studio not supporting arm64 in the design document (note that IntelliJ IDEs are using Java and can run on arm devices however the android build tools to create the apps aren't available for that platform).
Android host doesn't seem likely but that has a lot more to do with the OS itself. Your best bet would be Termux or similar (results will be of questionable success).
This PR is addressing Linux aarch64 host support. If you get Linux aarch64 environment on Android - sure. Otherwise, the PR is not relevant to your use case

OK, here is some background on what makes this solution work better than what we have been achieving with the existing engine design:

Engine layers are single purpose. If you want to do multiple operations, you have to break it up into multiple "engine layers" each of which work independently. Scale and Fade? That requires a TransformLayer and an OpacityLayer and they each operate on "children" - to try to combine their operations requires work by the engine to notice when those operations can be combined. So, while each engine layer can easily cache-optimize its own operations, the ability for a sequence of layers to cache-optimize their combined operations is missing in so many configurations and gets expensive to recognize when the authoring code (the widgets) already knew how the operations combined before they were forced to express the ops as individual nested layers.
It appears that the framework code here can decide to "cache and freeze" the children so that if the children continue to animate, it can ignore the subsequent changes in the children. Existing cache stability mechanism all rely on the children actually not changing, but this code will enforce that condition (presumably because widgets undergoing a transition effect don't need to be animating themselves?)
Overall, toGpuImage as an isolated mechanism should have similar performance to the caching in the engine layers in terms of getting pieces of scenes into images. But the resulting image can be dealt with more flexibly at the widget/RenderObject level than it can at the "each op is its own layer" engine level.

Yes, I think that sounds right.

it appears that the framework code here can decide to "cache and freeze" the children so that if the children continue to animate, it can ignore the subsequent changes in the children. Existing cache stability mechanism all rely on the children actually not changing, but this code will enforce that condition (presumably because widgets undergoing a transition effect don't need to be animating themselves?)

I would say more generally, the engine caching is conservative because it doesn't know the intention of the developer - and providing more hints is difficult since the engine caching decision happens very "far" from where the developer may have authored the code. The framework, or a particular widget, may decide to more agressively cache, and configuring that caching is something that is easier to discover by a developer. This caching may even amount to disabling an animation, which could be desirable if the performance is significant enough or if that animation or repainting is incindental

Another way to look at this PR is that you are answering the question of "what if I just wanted to express what I want to do with my children as a call to drawImage?" For this PR to work, it necessarily involves creating the GpuImage in order to express what you want - which means you have to involve caching in order to express a complex operation through the existing SceneBuilder API. What if we could break those 2 concepts up and so you could still express your transition as "drawScene(scene, geometric destination description (x,y or rects, nine-slice, etc), Paint, )" and then it could be used as a common way to present modifications of a set of children. That could be combined with either automatic or explicit caching to be able to do the entire zoom page transition in one operation. Even without caching, it would be a much more efficient operation. toGpuImage or the existing engine cache would become implementation details, but the API being presented would be this more flexible one that is independent of those details and would work well with them.

I'm also interested in hearing about the advantages we'd gain by adding API to the SceneBuilder that we otherwise would lose.

Are you talking about my comment about a potential drawScene(...)? FragmentShader is installed in a Paint so it would already be dealing with that. The transform is part of the operation just as if it would be with drawImage().
What I'm saying is that if you can express your operation as a call to drawImage - as this PR already implicitly requires - then it could be expressed as drawScene(...) which has all of the same bells and whistles as drawImage, but operates on a scene fragment.
We're not adding API to the SceneBuilder, we're removing API and replacing it with a more flexible operation.
pushOpacity should have never existed, it should have been drawScene(children, Paint..setAlpha).
pushImageFilter should have never existed, it should have been drawScene(children, Paint..setIF()).
pushColorFilter should have never existed, it should have been drawScene(children, Paint..setCF()).
pushTransform could be replaced by some variant of drawScene(children) with a transform.
At that point, pushOpacity nested with pushImageFilter becomes an obsolete concept replaced by drawScene(children, Paint..setThis..setThat).
And if the new transition involves perspective transforms, then it should already be expressable by the new mechanism because it can do anything you could have done with manual caching and a call to drawImage().

Also, I'm suggesting that a simpler near-term change would be that pushOpacity, pushImageFilter and pushColorFilter could very easily and non-disruptively be replaced by a single pushPaint. Those methods on SceneBuilder could still exist as special cases of pushPaint, but if we had had pushPaint all along, many of the "peephole optimization" complications that were part of the reason for this PR would have never been an issue.
And doing so combines 3 engine layers into 1, without any changes to framework code other than providing the framework with an opportunity to combine its layers if it so wishes.
To completely express most conceivable transition concepts, pushPaint isn't enough - we'd have to add a transform optimization into that. It isn't as "mostly delete code with a few lines added" trivial as adding pushPaint, but it is not that much work.
The longer term idea, though, is that pushSingleConceptFoo() is not a good API for us to have ever provided developers.

Where is the time spent in toGPUImage accounted? The call itself just returns a placeholder and puts a task on the rasterizer queue. The rasterization time reported in frame metrics is only the time to render the frame's layer tree itself. The other tasks are not timed or reported AFAICT.

Some more thoughts on the Gpu Images. Is there a mechanism to invalidate them and/or recreate them when the GPU is taken away from us? I'm not sure if that is still a thing, but I know back when we were creating Gpu images in Java (decades ago) we had to create a concept called VolatileImage that could tell you "I'm sorry, but my contents are missing and I have no way of getting them back, you'll have to abandon this object and recreate it" because most platforms could just dump your GPU assets outside of your control.
I looked at the native RasterCache and it looks like it has a Clear method that gets called from CompositorContext::OnGrContextCreated/Destroyed which appears to be a way to invalidate our native cache when these events occur.
So...

Does this GpuImage mechanism have a way to recover from that (which would either require remembering the scene/DL from which they were created and repopulating automatically, or notifying the framework so that it should recreate the image). I've added a fallback system that detects the first time a PlatformView or TextureView is encountered and errors out. We then provide a special delegate in the route transitions that make this not error out and instead fall back to pushing layers.
By default we don't handle these errors so users are discouraged from including platform views as children of these - though there is the option to disable this check if they don't care.
A future change will remove the restriction on texture view.

I found a problem with this approach. It breaks the invariant that Material relies on, namely that if it can find a Material.of during build, that guarantees that it can find the corresponding Material widget's render object during paint.
You can reproduce this problem by putting an InkWell inside an OverlayPortal's overlayChild and then tapping it.

My concern with z-index ordering is around the default behaviour, e.g. the way that having different ancestors (LayoutBuilder or not, for example, or SliverList or not) changes the z-index. For example, if you have something in a SliverList that shows an overlay, then something in a LayoutBuilder that shows one, the second will be above the first, but then if you scroll the list so that the item is dropped then scroll back so it comes back, suddenly the one in the list is on top... this seems fundamentally wrong to me, because as a developer it is unpredictable.

From a discussion with @LongCatIsLooong
For Views I have come to the conclusion that we need inheritance boundaries. There are certain widgets that should not flow into the View. One example is the Material widget. If you use a button in a subview, it should not see the Material widget in the main view because it doesn't make sense to draw the sparkles of the subview button into the main view. Instead, it should require that there is a Material widget in the subview itself.
I think it is the same for portals.
Also, we should make sure that OverlayPortals are a drop-in replacement for Views. Basically, OverlayPortals simulate sub-windows. We should probably hold off on this until the View stuff is a little further along. Fitting in Overlay Boundaries retro-actively doesn't sound like a good idea.

Having said that, it may be useful to draw a diagram of this implementation that visualizes how all the concepts used work together (e.g. who creates/owns/interacts with what). Maybe something like an extended UML diagram. That diagram could help with identifying potential simplifications and also document how the entire implementation works.
P.S. Looks like #114921 can be solved more easily if OverlayPortal (or flutter_portal) is available? Because then we seem to be able to control overlays more easily

Here's our thinking on this. In short: we see that, with the current template, developers introduce breaking changes to the template in the first 5 minutes of their work, and then the smoke test is broken (often statically broken, so there are analyzer errors and squiggly lines). The effect is that the (otherwise very educational!) test/widget_test.dart file gets deleted or commented out. For that reason, the approach is to have relatively trivial tests that can't be broken (they don't depend on lib/) but that still provide some boilerplate (test('...', () {})) and links to documentation.
Nothing here is set in stone, though.

We need to find a way to not duplicate the existing platform files. We occasionally have to update these, and having 2 copies of everything is going to increase the chances that we accidentally get out of sync somewhere.

flutter create tests live in https://github.com/flutter/flutter/blob/master/packages/flutter_tools/test/commands.shard/permeable/create_test.dart. We currently generate the app, analyze it, check formatting, etc., but we don't have devicelab tests that run it, AFAIK.

That was actually a really tricky call and we went back and forth on our final decision :)
In the end, to handle all of the use cases we wanted to (responsive design, web urls, etc), it felt like we had three options:

No argument passing (what we've got here)
"Hacky" argument passing -- short and sweet, but easy to break and doesn't really demonstrate how it should work
Full-featured argument passing -- Maybe a bit too much code for a template, much of it felt like it would need to be deleted or heavily modified by the end-user. Seemed better as a demonstration than a template.

My personal opinion: Navigator 2.0 handles the use cases we wanted to support, but it just requires a bit too much code right now.
The team is working on making the APIs simpler to use. Once that work has completed, the navigation patterns in this template should be updated.

Before we settle on skeleton, can we do a more thorough exploration of the naming possibilities? Those first three where just off the top of my head.

Other names to consider include:
Full
Standard
Starter

Android Studio uses more descriptive names like:
No Activity
Basic Activity
Full Screen Activity
Which we could translate into their Flutter equivalents, e.g. Multi-Screen.
VGV's new tool calls their app a "Starter App"
'yo' has thousands with no discernable pattern, so that's not a good source of inspiration

VS is more utilitarian, e.g.
Dynamic-link Library (DLL)
Static Library
Console App
Windows Desktop Application

I added some of the ideas to a form: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSc5XrLdqxMKUNHUGROJkncU316VbHHdGInU_VV5LLy2qDrpfQ/viewform?usp=sf_link

ASP.NET uses names like:
Core
Core Empty
Web API
gRPC Service (cool!)
Web Application

It's good to keep in mind this template adds to the following list of
Flutter templates:

  - app
  - module
  - package
  - plugin

That's why I chose `list_detail_app`. It seems descriptive and fitting for
the current naming structure.

Thanks everyone. I agree: There's no perfect name here, and I'm happy with skeleton as well :)
I saw some updates were pushed to this branch, but they looked a bit busted. There should only be about ~900 additions, nowhere near 8000. Therefore, I've rebased my branch against master to be sure this PR is up-to-date, renamed everything to skeleton, and force-pushed once again.
At this point, I think the plan for landing this PR seems to be:

Merge flutter_template_images: 3.0.0, which renames list_detail_app to skeleton: flutter/packages#310
Get any final input from the team and update this PR (all outstanding feedback so far has been addressed)
Rerun the CI checks for this PR and fix any issues. The flutter_tools pubspec for this PR already references flutter_template_images: 3.0.0, but of course no tests will pass until that's deployed.
Merge it up!

cc @stuartmorgan re: the use of non-default templates using a naming convention like "skeleton_app" or "federated_plugin" as he's particularly interested in adding a federated plugin template in the future.

I think it's plausible that we'll need a couple of new *_plugin types, but I don't have a strong opinion on whether that means this needs an *_app suffix; I don't see an issue with adding *_plugin templates even if this doesn't end with _app

The reason I'm not 100% on board with *_app is that it's not great developer experience on the command line. flutter create -t skeleton is easy to write and remember. flutter create -t skeleton_app not so much. ("Was it skeleton_app? Or skeleton_application? Or skeletonApp?")
I do understand the appeal of having a more stratified approach to naming. I just think we need to understand the tradeoff between that, and developer experience.
Perhaps we could have a policy that non-app templates get the suffix, e.g. skeleton is an app template but instead of using federated, we use federated_plugin.
We could also drop the underscore, as in "skeletonapp"

Here's a little bit of review feedback for @filiph as referenced to https://github.com/brianegan/new_flutter_template:

the settings page action is hidden behind the debug banner, which could be mitigated with a tooltip
I would expect settings to be a dialog on the desktop form factor and not a page to navigate to
I normally find myself having a shared Scaffold and AppBar between pages to reduce the duplicated code while providing a consistent UI between pages
the item details page has no Settings actions
I would expect the strings "Dummy Items" and "Item Details" to be in the arb and for the code to use them
all of the tests except the first two in implementation_test.dart have great comments; would like great comments in all tests

Thanks @csells, replies inline:

the settings page action is hidden behind the debug banner, which could be mitigated with a tooltip

We were aware of the issue but decided to prioritize simplicity of code. What do you mean by mitigating the issue with a tooltip?

I would expect settings to be a dialog on the desktop form factor and not a page to navigate to

That would make the code a lot more complex, and isn't necessarily all that clear cut. Desktop apps often open a completely separate window for settings screens, which would make things even harder to implement.

I normally find myself having a shared Scaffold and AppBar between pages to reduce the duplicated code while providing a consistent UI between pages

We explored this. In many cases, AppBar will be meaningfully different between pages. This can be mitigated by creating a custom widget, of course, but that would make the template more complex. And it's something where we don't need to educate. The template educates about things like file structure, but extracting widget is something an intermediate developer is perfectly capable of.
In short, this goes back to the goals of the template: getting out of the way of an intermediate/advanced developer.

the item details page has no Settings actions

That is intentional. In most apps we're seeing, app-level settings aren't accessible from everywhere. Of course, a desktop app has its settings in the menu, so in that sense, it's available everywhere. But again, this is something an intermediate developer should be able to implement themselves. And it allows us to save code that would otherwise need to be understood, modified and/or deleted by the developer.

I would expect the strings "Dummy Items" and "Item Details" to be in the arb and for the code to use them
all of the tests except the first two in implementation_test.dart have great comments; would like great comments in all tests

This is also intentional. We've seen that developers, when starting projects, don't immediately implement i18n everywhere. It really damages perceived developer productivity when, instead of Text('OK') you have to write the i18n equivalent (in several files).
In the template, we show how to go about doing i18n in Flutter, and give you the files in the right places and with the right contents, but don't implement it fully for you. As a developer, you'd be deleting most of it anyway.
